Monell v. Douglass. (New York Common Pleas

General Term,

April, 1893.) In a conveyance from defendant to plaintiff, the deed contained a covenant against incumbrances other than arrears of taxes and two mortgages; a suit to foreclose one of the mortgages was pending and the lis pendens filed; the action was discontinued, and the Ms pendens canceled upon plaintiff’s paying a certain amount. In an action upon the covenant a judgment for plaintiff was reversed upon the ground that the payment was voluntary. On a second trial, plaintiff again recovered judgment. Held, that the judgment should be reversed. As the court on appeal from the first judgment had determined that the facts pleaded did not ' constitute a cause of action it was the duty of the trial court upon the second trial, in the absence of amendment, to dismiss the complaint on defendant’s motion. Where a defendant at the trial protests against the litigation of a cause of action other than the one pleaded, the litigation and determination of such cause of action will not support a recovery, and a judgment for " plaintiff may be assailed. On the second trial plaintiff, over defendant’s objection, was allowed to prove that defendant by her agent orally agreed in consideration of an advance payment of part of the purchase price, to reimburse her for all outlays which she might necessarily incur to free her title to the property. Held, that in the absence of amendment to the complaint, the ■ admission of the evidence was error. Held, further, that a refusal to grant a motion to dismiss the complaint on the ground that the cause of action was not established by the evidence, was error. The court refused to charge at defendant’s request “that the jury were not at Ijberty to find for plaintiff upon any cause of action other than the one alleged in the complaint.” Defendant excepted. Held, that the refusal to charge was error. If a defendant objects, it is error to amend a complaint so as to substitute another cause of action for the one pleaded. Appeal from a judgment of the General Term of the City Court of New York which affirmed a judgment for plaintiff rendered at trial term upon a verdict in her favor. Action to recover damages for defendant’s alleged breach • of covenant against incumbrances in a deed for the conveyance of real property. George W. Wilson, for plaintiff (respondent). Thaddeus D. Kenneson, for defendant (appellant). *253Biscjetoff, J.

The complaint averred the execution and delivery of a deed by defendant to plaintiff for the conveyance of real property and the grantor’s covenant against incumbrances other than arrears of taxes and two certain mortgages with the accrued interest thereon, and that at the time of the conveyance an action had been begun in the Supreme Court for the foreclosure of one of the mortgages in which notice of the pendency of the action was duly filed. It further averred that to secure the discontinuance of the foreclosure action and the cancellation of notice of its pendency, plaintiff necessarily expended the sum of seventy-six dollars and twenty-five cents. For the sum so alleged to have been paid by her, plaintiff prayed judgment against defendant. The answer denied each of the material allegations of the complaint, except such as referred to the execution and delivery of the deed and the covenant against incumbrances therein. On a former appeal from a judgment for plaintiff this court, holding neither the foreclosure action nor the notice of its pendency to have constituted incumbrances, and deciding that plaintiff’s alleged payment was voluntary (Hayes v. Nourse, 114 N. Y. 595), reversed the judgment and directed that a new trial be had. Monell v. Douglass, 43 N. Y. St. Repr. 129. The second trial again resulted in a judgment for plaintiff, from which an appeal was also taken to this court, and at the November, 1892, General Term, the judgment was again reversed. A reargument of this last appeal was directed and had.

Searching scrutiny of the record only serves to confirm our first impression that the judgment must be reversed. It is apparent that after this court had on the former appeal determined that the facts pleaded did not constitute a cause of action, it was the duty of the trial court, in the absence of amendment, to dismiss the complaint, and its refusal so to do when thereunto moved by defendant’s counsel at the opening of the trial and before any evidence was adduced for either party, was palpable error.

Respondent’s counsel insists, however, that if facts constituting a cause of action, though not the one alleged in the *254complaint, be litigated and determined, the judgment is unassailable if the facts litigated and determined supported the recovery. He alludes to evidence in the record which tends to show that some time before the execution and delivery of the deed, defendant, by her duly-authorized agent, orally agreed, in consideration of tlm payment to her of part of the purchase money before the time contractually appointed, to reimburse plaintiff for all such outlays which she might necessarily incur to free her title to the real property subsequently conveyed to her from all objection. The contention is correct with the qualification that the defeated party did not protest against the litigation of a cause of action other than the one pleaded. Knapp v. Simon, 96 N. Y. 284; Fallon v. Lawler, 102 id. 228; Williams v. People's Fire Ins. Co., 57 id. 274; Tyng v. Commercial Warehouse Co., 58 id. 308.

Rut defendant did protest. The evidence of the alleged oral agreement is to be found in the testimony of plaintiff’s witness Hibbard. This testimony was specifically objected to by defendant’s counsel. Furthermore, counsel moved the dismissal óf the complaint when plaintiff rested, and again when the introduction of evidence was closed on both sides, each time urging as the ground for the motion that the cause of action was not established by the evidence. Then again he distinctly requested the trial court to charge that the jury were not at liberty to find for plaintiff upon any cause of action other than the one alleged in the complaint, which request was refused, and exception taken to the refusal. No amendment of the complaint was applied for on the trial, and indeed it would have been error to have granted it against defendant’s objection if the amendment in effect was intended to substitute another cause of action for the one pleaded. Romeyn v. Sickles, 108 N. Y. 650 ; 1 Silvernail, 594; Baylies’ Code Pleading, 321 et seq.

We are constrained, therefore, to hold that there was a total failure of proof of the cause of action alleged (Code Civ. Proc. § 541; Arnold v. Angell, 62 N. Y. 508 ; Southwick v. First Natl. Bank of Memphis, 84 id. 420; Shrimpton v. *255Dworsky, 2 Misc. Rep. 123), and that the trial court erred in its refusal of the several motions for dismissal of the complaint, and again in refusing to charge the jury as requested by defendant’s counsel.

The judgment is reversed, with costs to appellant to abide the event.

Daly, Oh. J., and Pryor, J., concur.

Judgment reversed, costs to abide event.
